title: Frente Popular (Goa)
text:
The Frente Popular Party (also named Janta Agadhi) is a former political party of <a href="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It participated in the 1963 Goa general elections without any success.
Background.
Frente Popular was founded by <a href="communists">communists</a>. Its stated ideals were <a href="secularism">secularism</a>, <a href="democracy">democracy</a> and <a href="socialism">socialism</a>. It attacked the <a href="prohibition">prohibition</a> policy promoted by the <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">Congress</a> and criticized the administration of Goa for nepotism and corruption.
Frente Popular was responsible for organizing mass rallies which were addressed by prominent national communist leaders such as <a href="S.%20A.%20Dange">S. A. Dange</a>. It was headed by <a href="Bertha%20Menezes%20Braganza">Bertha Menezes Braganza</a>, a journalist from <a href="Bombay">Bombay</a>.
Views on Goa's statehood.
There were persistent demands to merge the Union Territory of Goa into the newly created linguistic state of <a href="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>. The communists in India were staunch supporters of the <a href="Samyukta%20Maharashtra%20movement">Samyukta Maharashtra movement</a>, which demanded an enlarged linguistic state of Maharashtra, which included Goa. However, the Frente Popular campaigned against a merger and supported full statehood for Goa.
1963 elections.
There were eight political parties in Goa at the time of the first general elections in 1963; however, only four got recognition from the <a href="Election%20Commission%20of%20India">Election Commission of India</a>, including the Frente Popular. The symbol allocated to the Frente Popular was the <a href="elephant">elephant</a>.
Frente Popular put forth only eight candidates from the 30 available constituencies. It contested mainly in areas with high concentrations of labourers, fielding candidates from the <a href="trade%20unions">trade unions</a>. Bertha Menezes Braganza ran in <a href="Cortalim">Cortalim</a>. The party did not win any seats, polling just 4,548 votes (1.82% of polled votes). The <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>'s campaign for the <a href="United%20Goans%20Party">United Goans Party</a> has been cited as a major factor contributing to the party's poor showing.
